content.description:
Fun moves up to the crux which involves a terrible undercling crimp with your right hand and then move high with your left hand...possibly bump... up to a good ledge. From here there is some mantling to be done.

Sort of heads up the arete to the right of Cling-on Opposition.
5 bolts. You may want to consider stick clipping the first bolt. Top anchors.

Ready for some crazy ass oppositional / side-pull moves off shit holds and barely-there feet? I literally have no idea how this is climbable: First two bolts is hard but the moves are all there: reach real far for a first right hand crimp. Pull up and get your left hand high to a good crimp. Put your feet somewhere, then move up with your right hand to a temporary crimp, then bump to a higher nice crimp. Rearrange feet, then grab a left hand crimper then bump up to the only good hold on this route. From here, you have a nice undercling/side-pull for your right hand. Clip the second clip from here. From here it looks like side-pull oppositional crazy business. The very ending is easy, but from the second bolt to the fifth bolt it's all nonsense.

Above the giant flake, to the right of Pin Heads from Space.
4 bolts. Stick clip the first bolt (seriously, don't be a bad ass: this is a place you do not want to fall). Top anchors.

Very fun climb. Head up and right, and then left over the lip. Set by the Association of Canadian Mountain Guides (ACMG).

Left most route in the Upper Canyon, to the right of the fixed line. Left of a very fun trad climb that goes up a large crack.
4 bolts with top anchors.

Start at the very bottom: don't cheat by starting higher up to the right. This climb sort-of heads up the right-facing edge, but the bolts are far left. Try to stay on the face while using the side-pull to the right. It's more fun this way, and seems to be more in-line with the vision the person who bolted this had.

Farthest bolted route right in the Upper Canyon.
3 bolts and top anchors.

Bring your A game! This route is powerful off the ground. Search for good hands, use opposing feet, bumb and squeeze! The arete provides for your right, but you need to something for your left hand. A big balancy move to a jug will get you out of that bouldery section. Climb the arete and corner to the next bolt. Tuck under the rock and exit right. Anchors straight up.

4 bolts, anchors up right

climbs.name: Pin Heads from Space
climbs.fa: Bolted by Alain Dallaire and first bolted ascent

content.description:
Move from the giant flake to a nice undercling. Right hand up to a barely good pinch/sloper. Left hand up high to a good crimp. Crux: rearrange feet, move your right hand up to a temporary hold and then bump up to the knife-like bomber hold. Get both hands on that and move up to some great side-pulls and underclings. Head up from there on some great holds.

Above a giant flake.
4 bolts and top anchors

Crimpy blank face climbing up to a good ledge. To reach that ledge, you may want to use a semi-good side-pull crimp. From the ledge, get the undercling, and head hiiiigh up to the pocket that gives this climb it's name. From here you're home free. 
 note: this climb can get really dirty and because of how small some of the crimps are, can be difficult depending on how much mud has slid down onto the face.

3 bolts and top anchors.

Crux is a reachy move off the pedestal, 5.9 if you're short.



30m to the climbers left of Dynosaur 

3 bolts

5.8L where L stands for "Lichenated". Should clean up in about 100y. Good alternative start to the climb on the left for those who are short.



About 30m to the climbers left of Dynosaur 

1 bolt, crack will take gear, but should TR until it's a bit cleaner

Climb up a weird broken crack. Head left and place some large gear (3") and then head right up to the anchors.

To the right of Dynosaur. Large weird crack.
Takes cams up to 3". Anchors at top.

Climb follows bolts up to the left around a roof then traverses out right above the roof.

Anchors at the top.

Follows crips to ledges to bolted anchors. 

Anchors at top.

Head up to the horizontal crack, then up to the bolts. 

Anchors at top.

Head left on tiny ledges to a flake system. Then head right up under the roof. Use some burley moves to pull the roof (crux). 
 note: I have not climbed this, but watched some pro climb it and it was like seeing the face of God. He almost on-sighted the bitch. Looks awesome.

Look for the bolts that lead to a giant roof.
4 bolts and top anchors.
Sunny in the afternoon. Can get pretty buggy. Crowded for Yukon standards, but less crowded than the other area in the Rocker Gardens. Granite.
